results.title: Penguins off the page
results.brief_description: A biology teacher struggles to make his students pay attention to his lesson on different species of penguins. Little does he know that the very penguins he is discussing have come to life on his desktop, providing an amusing performance that brings his words to life. A plasticine animation in a live action classroom.
results.description: A biology teacher struggles to make his students pay attention to his lesson on different species of penguins. results.title: Penguins off the page
results.creator_credit: Jon Rowdon and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “RMIT Collection”.
A plasticine animation in a live action classroom. Today’s biology lesson is about the different types of penguins. The peculiar magic of wildlife comes to the classroom as penguins colonise his desk to bring each of the species of penguins to life. As the lesson progresses the class watches each species appear and play amongst the mess on the teacher’s desk.

results.title: Penguin island: Australia's little penguins
results.creator_credit: BandG Communications, Gordon Badham and Patrick Gillespie
results.brief_description: Hosted by Peter Hoskings, this is a tourist orientated film that never the less provides a wealth of facts and figures about the fairy penguins, and background information about Phillip Island. Excellent cinematography reveals much about the scenary and wild life of the island including koalas, kangaroos and wallabies, wombats, seals, wild flowers and birds.

results.title: Penguin Island
results.brief_description: A film record of the various types of animal life found by the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition (1948-1950) during their stay on Macquarie Island. Shows many species of seals, penguins and birds, including the Great Wandering Albatross. Recordings of sounds made by penguins are used in the introduction to the film.
results.description: A film record of the various types of animal life found by the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition (1948-1950) during their stay on Macquarie Island. results.title: Penetrator for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette & cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Penetrator is a side scrolling shooter for one or two players for the Commodore 64. The player flies a fighter across the screen from left to right, dodging terrain and enemy shots and shooting enemy structures. Players can accelerate and brake their fighter but prolonged braking can stall it. Enemies become more accurate the longer the player is exposed to the radar and the danger level is shown on the player’s console. The game can also be customised for landscape and the number and positions of enemy missile and radar bases.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1982 by Melbourne House

results.title: Pending
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Paola Garofali and Anna Tow
results.brief_description: In this fantasy animation, Jasmine flees her war-torn country for the safety of the towering City of Anchors. But between her traumatic past and her hopes for a new life, Jasmine must first face a heartless Immigration Department bureaucrat and persuade him to let her stay. Original Format 35 mm/colour.

results.title: Pencils
results.brief_description: Scenes showing children and adults writing, drawing, and doodling with every imaginable kind of pencil are intercut with sequences filmed at a factory where pencils are manufactured. The variety of pencils, sizes, shapes, colours and uses are conveyed without narration but with a lively musical score.

The variety of pencils, sizes, shapes, colours and uses are conveyed without narration but with a lively musical score.

results.title: Penance: Sacrament of peace
results.creator_credit: Franciscan Communications Centre and Bruce Bailer
results.brief_description: A dramatisation illustrating the universal story of sin, repentance, reconciliation and peace. Ray Hendricks, driving home from a cocktail party, accidentally strikes a little girl. He tries to cover up his guilt and remorse by attempting to convince himself and others that because he was cleared by the police, he is not guilty of anything. He finally risks the confrontation and visits the little girl. She gives him sympathy because he looks hurt, and her naive assumption of this basic goodness brings him peace.

results.title: Penalty kicks, free kicks and goal keeping
results.brief_description: Begins by dividing the action of taking a penalty kick into its five aspect. Demonstrates the strategies involved in scoring opportunities from direct free kicks near the penalty areas. Santos and Claudio shows the skills associated with goalkeeping.

results.title: Pen point percussion: an introduction to hand-drawn sound of Norman McLaren
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Tom Daly
results.brief_description: The first part of this film presents an explanation of the principles and production of synthetic sound in motion pictures, showing Norman McLaren’s experimentation with hand-drawn sounds on film. The film is designed as an introduction to McLaren’s animated productions. An oscilloscope records what various sounds look like - the trembling strings of a guitar, the low tones of a tuba, the crow of a rooster and the human speaking voice. Norman McLaren then demonstrates on a moviola the sounds that emit from a soundtrack on which he has drawn dots, lines and triangles and we note how these sounds are synchronised with the artist’s hand-drawn animations. (6 mins.) Written by Don Peter. Photographed by Lorne C. Batchelor. Music by Louis Applebaum. (Award: Venice). The second part presents Norman McLaren’s experimental film ‘Dots’ made in 1948 which demonstrates his innovative technique and illustrates what can be created by drawing directly onto the picture and soundtrack area of film stock. (2 mins.) Other films in the collection related to this technique include ‘The Eye hears the ear sees’, ‘Synchronomy’ and ‘Loops’. (Awards: Toronto, Salerno, Rome)
